titlestmt.title: The Book of Thel Copy O : electronic edition
titlestmt.respstmt: Programmer/Analysts: Robert Bingler and David CoscaProject Manager: Matthew KirschenbaumProject Assistant: Greg Murray

filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 80KB; 16 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 25KB to 550KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Charlottesville: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; IATH November 1996
filedesc.updatestmt:
The editors of the Blake Archive are pleased to announce that Copies F, H, and O of The Book of Thel and Copies a, C, and J of Visions of the Daughters of Albion are now publicly accessible. The images are linked to enlargements and to transcriptions edited to correspond to the particular copy; plates are displayed in the order they appear in the copy and are identified by that order, as well as by their Bentley, Erdman, and Keynes plate numbers.
The source of the digital images are new 4x5 color transparencies, which were color corrected against the originals. They were scaled to the size of the originals and scanned in 24-bit color at 300dpi. The resulting digital images, which were color corrected against the transparencies, are displayed as jpeg images, at 100dpi and at 300dpi. The former image will be displayed larger or smaller than the original depending on your monitor's resolution. In the near future, though, using a program being developed by the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities , you will be able to receive these images resized on the fly according to your monitor's resolution.
We will continue to make copies of illuminated books accessible once we have scanned and color corrected the images and edited the texts. In the next few months, we will display The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy D, Urizen Copy G, Song of Los Copy B, Europe Copies B and E, and America Copy E. We will also post a general bibliography on Blake and select bibliographies for each of these books, as well as Erdman's edition of Blake's poetry and prose. Users will thus be able to browse the Archive, downloading images and texts (for private use only). When the search engine is operational, they will also be able to search the Archive for words, visual motifs, or bibliographical information, because we are also encoding all texts, plates, and images in Standard General Markup Language (see Plan of the Archive).
We presently have over 1200 transparencies of a projected 3000 for the Archive. With the entire Rosenwald Collection of illuminated books and the Essick Collection of prints, as well as works from the Glasgow University Library and the New York Public Library, we have at least one copy of every illuminated book, major series of prints (Book of Job, Dante illustrations, Night Thoughts, etc.), and commercial engraving. We will be adding paintings and manuscripts as we add other important collections to the Archive. Scanning, editing, and encoding all of these images will keep the site under construction for the next few years.
Users can visit this page for future updates about our progress and about future developments at the Institute that affect the Archive, such as INOTE (written in the programming language Java), a tool that makes it possible for users to search, enlarge, compare, and annotate images.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.publisher: William BlakeBlake is recorded as the author and printer on the title page but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: LondonThe place of publication is not recorded in the work, but Blake lived in London or its suburb, Lambeth, during the etching of the copperplates. He lived in London during the printing of this copy.

objdescid.compdate: 1789Objects 7 and 8 (Bentley Plates 8 and 1) may have been composed at a slightly later date (late 1789 or early 1790) than the others. These same two objects were probably etched later than the others (late 1789 or early 1790).

objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates 2-8, 1 The placement of "Thel's Motto" (Bentley Plate 1) at the end of this copy is authorized by Blake's pen and ink number, "8," inscribed on it. This is also true of Copy N, like Copy O printed in 1818.
objinfo.medium: relief etching and hand coloring in water colors and touches of shell gold.
objinfo.watermark: RUSE & TURNERS/1815The watermark appears only in the leaves bearing Objects 2 and 7 (Bentley Plates 3 and 8).
objinfo.etchednumbers: Numbered 1-6 on Objects 2-7The etched numbers are either very lightly printed or partly obscured by marginal designs.
objinfo.pennednumbers: 1-8The numbers are written in black ink over pencil on Objects 1-7; the number on Object 8 is in pen and black ink, possibly over pencil. The pen and ink numbers were probably intended to supersede the etched numbers.
objinfo.framelines: noneSome objects have a pen and black ink outline drawn at the edges of the images.
objinfo.binding: bound with *Milton* Copy D in half calf over marbled boards, an earlier morocco backstrip pasted over the calf
objinfo.stabholes: six holes, 4.6 cm. from the top and 4.1, 3.9, 4.5, 4.5, and 4.5 cm. apart; later, twelve holes when bound with *Milton* Copy D

provenance.name: Library of Congress
provenance.date: 1939 by Lessing J. Rosenwald; given to the Library of Congress in 1945.
provenance.note: Originally acquired from Blake by James Vine; bound with *Milton* Copy D and sold from Vine's collection, Christie's, 24 April 1838, lot 297 (£5.12s.6d. to the dealer Henry Bohn); offered by Bohn, 1841 *Catalogue of Books*, item 178 (not priced) and *Catalogue of Books*, 1847 and 1848 issues, vol. 1, page 259, no item number (£10.10s.); Benjamin Godfrey Windus; G. P. de Putron by inheritance in 1867; sold Sotheby's, 11 Dec. 1923, lot 252 (£3400 to "Pickering"—probably the book dealer Pickering & Chatto, possibly acting from Frank Bemis); Bemis no later than 1925; sold in 1939 through the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach to Lessing J. Rosenwald, who gave the two works still bound together to the Library of Congress in 1945.

repository.department: Rare Book and Special Collections Division

desc.objtitle: THE BOOK of THEL, Object 1 (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender tree, entwined with a vine, arches protectively over the title words and major pictorial motifs. This combination of motifs and their position suggests a tombstone. Two birds and a human figure soar in the sky; seven other human forms, one winged, rest or climb among the title letters. Thel, wearing a long gown and holding a shepherd's crook, stands lower left and gazes at a nude man embracing a gowned woman around her waist. She raises her arms. These figures seem to emerge from the large, bowl-like flowers lower center and right. The leaves of this plant and a flower bud complete the design lower center and right. The design does not directly illustrate a scene in the text, but the figures embracing above the flowers may suggest the "raptures" (Plate 4 [5], line 13) of the Cloud and the "fair eyed dew" (Plate 4 [5], line 15) during their courtship.

component.illusobjdesc: A large, willow-like tree arches over the title words and major pictorial motifs. This shape, with letters within, suggests the outline of a tombstone. It splits into several branches (perhaps bearing long, slender leaves) on the right.
A slender vine twines around the over-arching tree. Some of the vine's branches bear flowers and/or leaves.

Two open flowers and one bud bloom from the slender stems of a plant. These flowers may be the pasqueflower (anemone pulsatilla). They seem to be blown to the left by a gentle wind. The plant's large leaves bend to the ground. Three stems bearing spiky leaves, or the remnants of blossoms, or perhaps grain tassels also grow from the plant.
A vine or miniature tree arches over the figure seated and leaning against the B of the word "Book" (line 3).
Vines or tendrils grow from all four letters of the word "Book" (line 3).
Flame-like leaves spring from the first O of the word "Book" (line 3).

A flower, similar in shape to the much larger ones below, blooms from the K of the word "Book" (line 3). Two long stamens curve upward from the flower. There may also be an upright plant sprouting from the bottom left serif of the K in "Book." There are slight indications of leaves along its stem.
Slender vines twine about the letters of "Thel" (line 5). Two form empty spirals.

Thel, wearing a gown and holding a shepherd's crook, stands in a delicate contrapposto posture and looks upon the figures and flowers on the right. Her long hair curls over her shoulders; the hem of her gown curls about her feet and over the ground.

A gowned, apparently youthful, female hovers to the left of an open flower. She raises both arms above her head as a nude male embraces her waist. Her legs are spread apart as though she were striding to the left. Strands of her long hair can be seen left of her torso.
A nude, apparently youthful, man hovers to the left of an open flower and embraces a young woman around her waist. His legs are spread apart.

A seated human figure, perhaps reading or writing in a book or tablet, sits and leans against the vertical of the letter B in the word "Book" (line 3). The figure's right leg dangles downward; the left leg appears to be crossed over the right upper leg.
A human figure, probably male, stands within the second O of "Book" (line 3). He wears a hat and holds a shepherd's crook.
A young man, apparently wearing tights, climbs the vertical of the letter T in "Thel" (line 5). He probably turns his face upward.
A gowned young woman stands on the foot of the left vertical of the letter H in "Thel" (line 5). She raises both arms above her head and appears to be facing up.
A gowned young woman stands on or hovers just above the horizontal of the letter H in "Thel" (line 5). She raises both her arms above her head.
A very small figure stands just to the right of the second vertical of H in "Thel" (line 5).

A gowned woman hovers above the letters E and L of "Thel" (line 5). Her legs extend to the left; her arms are raised horizontally. She may be holding a fancifully-shaped bow in her left hand, or these swirls may be vines springing from her hand. The tail of her long gown floats behind her.
A gowned angel with large wings sits on the horizontal, and leans against the vertical, of the letter L of "Thel" (line 5). The figure may be reading the book or tablet propped against his (?) knees.
A bird, wings extended, soars left of the word "of" in the title (line 4).
A bird, wings extended, soars right of the word "of" in the title (line 4).
Some of the washes in the sky suggest clouds.
The title words are integrated into the full-page design.

lg.l: THE BOOK of THEL

l.note: The penned number ("1") is written in ink over pencil.

lg.l: THE
BOOK
of
THEL
The Author & Printer Willm Blake. 1789

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four human figures soar around the title-word "Thel": a nude man reaching toward a large eagle, a nude man holding a sword and shield, and a gowned woman holding a small child in her outstretched arms. Below, a fifth figure, a nude man, rests on the branch of a tree (or perhaps a tassel of grain) and looks up toward the child. Spiraling vines and stylized flowers, perhaps lilies, spring from several of the title letters. A tree grows up the far left margin; a few spiky lines at the bottom of the plate probably delineate grass or some other sort of low vegetation. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design. The design does not represent any specific incident in the text, but the man with shield and spear may be one of the "thousand fighting men" referred to near the end of the poem (Plate 7 [8], line 16).

component.illusobjdesc: Two vines, each terminating in what may be lily-like flowers, spring from the lower-left termination of the T of "Thel" (line 2).
A spiral vine descends from the H of "Thel" (line 2).
A vine spirals upwards from the L of "Thel" (line 2). It terminates in what may be a flower, perhaps a lily.
A spiky form that may be a stylized lily springs from the top-left corner of the H of "Thel" (line 2).
A small vine, branching at its lower end, hovers between the feet of the T and H in "Thel" (line 2).
A small vine extends horizontally beneath the E and L of "Thel" (line 2).
Two small vines extend horizontally above the T and the first vertical of the H in "Thel" (line 2).
One of the figures rests on a tree branch or, if the perspective is microscopic, a tassel of grain. Another branch arches over his head.
A nude man hovers in the air, legs spread and with his right arm reaching (or pointing with one finger) toward an eagle.
A nude male hovers in the air. He holds a sword with a spiraling blade in his right hand; a shield is apparently strapped to his left arm.
A nude man reclines on a branch or tassel of grain. He props himself up with his right arm and turns his head upward.
A gowned woman hovers in the air. Her outstretched arms hold a young child.
An infant or young child hovers in the air, supported by a woman's outstretched arms. The child's legs are spread apart and its right arm may be extended toward the woman.
A large bird, probably an eagle, soars above the title-word "Thel" (line 2). Its prominent beak is open.
Several lines in the illustration appear to indicate the outlines of clouds, particularly in the top left corner.
The letters in the heading are integrated into the design.

lg.l: THEL

component.illusobjdesc: A tree grows up the far left margin of the plate and divides into two branches at the top. Alternatively, if the perspective here is microscopic, this may be a stem of grain with a tassel at the top.
A few spiky lines probably delineate grass or some other sort of low vegetation in the lower margin of the plate.

l.note: The penned number ("2") is written in ink over pencil.
In Copy O, this number ("1") is very lightly printed from the plate. Presumably, the inscribed number above (line 1) supersedes this lightly-printed number.

lg.l: The daughters of Mne Seraphim led round their sunny flocks,
All but the youngest, she in paleness sought the secret air.
To fade away like morning beauty from her mortal day:
Down by the river of Adona her soft voice is heard:
And thus her gentle lamentation falls like morning dew.
O life of this our spring! why fades the lotus of the water?
Why fade these children of the spring? born but to smile & fall.
Ah! Thel is like a watry bow. and like a parting cloud.
Like a reflection in a glass. like shadows in the water.
Like dreams of infants, like a smile upon an infants face,
Like the doves voice, like transient day. like music in the air:
Ah! gentle may I lay me down. and gentle rest my head.

And gentle sleep the sleep of death. and gentle hear the voiceAt the end of the ninth word ("gentle") in line 17, Blake first wrote "e" and then wrote "y" over it before etching the copper plate. Both letters printed in proof Copy a and possibly Copy C; Blake then removed the "e" from the copper and printed the word as "gently" in Copies K and R. He then reshaped the "y" into an "e" on the copper plate and printed the word as "gentle" in all other copies, sometimes strengthening the "e" in pen and ink.
Of him that walketh in the garden in the evening time.
The Lilly of the valley breathing in the humble grass
Answerd the lovely maid and said: I am a watry weed,
And I am very small, and love to dwell in lowly vales;
So weak. the gilded butterfly scarce perches on my head
Yet I am visited from heaven. and he that smiles on all.
Walks in the valley. and each morn over me spreads his hand
Saying, rejoice thou humble grass. thou new-born lilly flower,
Thou gentle maid of silent valleys. and of modest brooks:
For thou shalt be clothed in light, and fed with morning manna;
Till summers heat melts thee beside the fountains and the springs
To flourish in eternal vales: then why should Thel complain,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel stands beneath the arching branches of a tree, perhaps a birch or willow. She bows slightly toward the personified Lilly who, with arms folded, bows more deeply toward Thel. Both females wear long gowns, ruffled along the hems. A vine climbs lazily about the tree trunk. This vine seems to grow from the plant right of Thel. The plant behind and to the right of the Lilly is probably a lily, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily. A second tree trunk appears along the right margin of the design. Washes in the text area suggest a sky with clouds. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design. The design illustrates the dialogue between Thel and the Lilly given in the text on this plate. The moment pictured may be their parting, when "the Lilly bowd her modest head" (line 18).

component.illusobjdesc: Part of a tree trunk extends along the right margin of the design.
A tree with arching branches forms a canopy over the figures. It may be a birch or willow. Small leaves dangle from the smaller branches on the left.
A plant with spiky leaves grows between Thel and the left-most tree. Flowering, vine-like stems curl in front of the tree.
A large lily plant, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily, blooms behind and to the right of the personified Lilly. It bears at least three flowering stems.
A few spiky lines and the coloring of the ground suggest grass along the lower margin of the plate.

Thel, wearing a long gown with a ruffled hem, stands with her arms at her side in a slightly bowed posture, facing to the left. Her long hair falls over her shoulders. Her feet (right foot forward) are bare.
The personified Lilly bows, with arms apparently folded, toward Thel. The hem of the Lilly's gown is elaborately ruffled. She appears to hover above the ground in front of the vegetation.
Washes along the right margin suggest the sky at sunrise or sunset.
Some of the washes suggest the outlines of clouds in the sky, including areas around and within the text.

l.note: The penned number ("3") is written in ink over pencil.
In Copy O, this printed number ("2") is partly obscured by a marginal design. Presumably, the inscribed number above (line 1) supersedes this number.

lg.l: Why should the mistress of the vales of Har, utter a sigh.
She ceasd & smild in tears, then sat down in her silver shrine.
Thel answerd, O thou little virgin of the peaceful valley.

Giving to those that cannot crave, the voiceless, the o'erfired.In Copy O, the period at the end of the line is much higher, in relation to the letters in the line, than is customary. Perhaps this is actually the upper point of a colon or semicolon in which the lower element was not etched or did not print.
Thy breath doth nourish the innocent lamb. he smells thy milky garments,
He crops thy flowers. while thou sittest smiling in his face,
Wiping his mild and meekin mouth from all contagious taints.
Thy wine doth purify the golden honey, thy perfume,
Which thou dost scatter on every little blade of grass that springs.
Revives the milked cow, & tames the fire-breathing steed.
But Thel is like a faint cloud kindled at the rising sun;
I vanish from my pearly throne, and who shall find my place.
Queen of the vales the Lilly answerd, ask the tender cloud,
And it shall tell thee why it glitters in the morning sky.
And why it scatters its bright beauty thro' the humid air.
Descend O little cloud & hover before the eyes of Thel,
The Cloud descended. and the Lilly bowd her modest head:
And went to mind her numerous charge among the verdant grass.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Forms along the left margin suggest a cliff or the side of a tree trunk. Some of the washes throughout the illustration may indicate the outlines of clouds. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design.

component.illusobjdesc: A tree trunk or cliff rises along the left margin.
Washes throughout the illustration may define clouds at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two vines, one bearing lily-like flowers, spring from the beginning of the first line of verse (line 3).

component.illusobjdesc: Two vines, one bearing lily-like flowers, spring from the beginning of the first line of verse (line 3).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine or two branches grow from the end of the last line of verse (line 33).

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or two branches grow from the end of the last line of verse (line 33).

l.note: The penned number ("4") is written in ink over pencil.
In Copy O, only the bottom half of this number ("3") printed. Presumably, the inscribed number above (line 1) supersedes this number.

lg.l: O little Cloud the virgin said. I charge thee tell to me.
Why thou complainest not when in one hour thou fade away:
Then we shall seek thee but not find; ah Thel is like to thee.
I pass away. yet I complain, and no one hears my voice.
The Cloud then shewd his golden head & his bright form emerg'd,
Hovering and glittering on the air before the face of Thel.
O virgin know'st thou not: our steeds drink of the golden springs
Where Luvah doth renew his horses: look'st thou on my youth,
And fearest thou because I vanish and am seen no more.
Nothing remains; O maid I tell thee. when I pass away;
It is to tenfold life. to love. to peace. and raptures holy:
Unseen descending, weigh my light wings upon balmy flowers:
And court the fair eyed dew. to take me to her shining tent;
The weeping virgin. trembling kneels before the risen sun.
Till we arise link'd in a golden band. and never part;
But walk united, bearing food to all our tender flowers
Dost thou O little Cloud? I fear that I am not like thee;
For I walk through the vales of Har, and smell the sweetest flowers:
But I feed not the little flowers: I hear the warbling birds,
But I feed not the warbling birds. they fly and seek their food:
But Thel delights in these no more because I fade away,
And all shall say, without a use this shining woman liv'd,
Or did she only live. to be at death the food of worms.
The Cloud reclind upon his airy throne and answer'd thus.
Then if thou art the food of worms. O virgin of the skies,
How great thy use, how great thy blessing; every thing that lives,
Lives not alone. nor for itself: fear not and I will call
The weak worm from its lowly bed, and thou shalt hear its voice.
Come forth worm of the silent valley, to thy pensive queen.
The helpless worm arose, and sat upon the Lillys leaf,
And the bright Cloud saild on, to find his partner in the vale.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel stands center right, accompanied by the personified Cloud and Worm. Her arms, raised horizontally, imitate the gesture of the cloud, a nude male (except for a slip of drapery) hovering in the air. The hem of Thel's gown seems to be ruffled by the same breeze on which the Cloud floats. The Worm, portrayed as an infant, rests in a bed formed by a lily plant. Several flowers on a single stem are pictured just to the left of the infant Worm. A large tree and spiraling vine dominate the right margin. The design would seem to illustrate the last two lines of verse on the previous plate and the first line of verse on this plate: "The helpless worm arose, and sat upon the Lillys leaf, / and the bright Cloud saild on, to find his partner in the vale. / . . . Then Thel astonish'd view'd the Worm upon its dewy bed" (Object 4, lines 33-34; Object 5, line 3).

component.illusobjdesc: The trunk of a large tree, perhaps a birch, is pictured along the right margin. A short limb divides into two slender branches.
A vine bearing a single leaf spirals upward in front of and to the left of the tree.

A large plant with spiky leaves, possibly a St. Bernard's lily, forms a bed for the infant Worm. A long vine-like tendril trails to the left. A sprig and two small clusters of flowers appear left of the Worm.
A few spiky lines indicate grass or a small plant to the left of the tree.
A few wavy lines and the green coloring indicate grass covering the ground along the lower margin of the upper design.

Thel stands with arms raised horizontally, as if imitating the Cloud's gestures, and looks down at the personified Worm. The hem of her gown flutters to the left, as though blown by a breeze, but her long hair seems blown to the right. She may be striding away from the viewer and to the left. Her feet, left foot forward, are bare.

The personified Cloud hovers in the air, his arms raised horizontally and his legs apart, the left bent at the knee. He is basically nude, but a flag-like piece of drapery trails behind him. His long hair floats to the right. His head is turned back slightly to the right.
The personified Worm, a nude infant boy(?), lies among the leaves and blossoms of a lily plant. He may be looking up and to the right, towards Thel.
Some of the washes and touches of shell gold in the sky may indicate clouds.

The hem of Thel's gown and the posture of the personified Cloud suggest a wind blowing from right to left. However, the position of these characters' long hair suggests a breeze in the opposite direction.
Washes in the sky in the upper design suggest a sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There may be a cliff or the edge of a tree trunk on the far left margin. A tree or vine with large roots climbs the right margin. Some of the washes around the text may indicate clouds or, at the top, water.

component.illusobjdesc: The washes along the left margin of the text may suggest a tree trunk or a cliff.
A tree or vine with large roots climbs up the right margin of the text.
The washes around the text may indicate clouds or, at the top left, water.

l.note: The penned number ("5") is written in ink over pencil.
In Copy O, this number ("4") is very lightly printed. Presumably, the inscribed number above (line 1) supersedes this lightly-printed number.

lg.l: Then Thel astonish'd view'd the Worm upon its dewy bed.
Art thou a Worm? image of weakness. art thou but a Worm?
I see thee like an infant wrapped in the Lillys leaf:
Ah weep not little voice, thou can'st not speak, but thou can'st weep;
Is this a Worm? I see thee lay helpless & naked: weeping;
And none to answer, none to cherish thee with mothers smiles.
The Clod of Clay heard the Worms voice, & raisd her pitying head;
She bowd over the weeping infant, and her life exhal'd
In milky fondness. then on Thel she fix'd her humble eyes.
O beauty of the vales of Har. we live not for ourselves.
Thou seest me the meanest thing, and so I am indeed;
My bosom of itself is cold. and of itself is dark,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel squats on the ground, arms folded, and looks at the personified Worm and Clod (or "matron Clay" [line 15]). Her long hair cascades over her shoulders; the hem of her long gown billows around her. The infant Worm extends both arms and looks at the Clod, a young, nude woman lying on the ground. She may be reaching for her offspring. Right of Thel is a large plant with spiky leaves and two blossoms, one of which arches over Thel's head. Left of Thel is another plant with similar leaves but no blossoms. Blake has added water on the left and in the foreground, suggesting a river or lake. Given this configuration, the figures may be on an island or peninsula. A cliff or edge of a tree trunk rises along the left margin. Washes beneath and on all sides of the text may indicate clouds. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design. The design may in part illustrate lines on the previous plate: "The Clod of Clay heard the Worms voice, & raisd her pitying head; / She bow'd over the weeping infant..." (Plate 5, lines 9-10).

component.illusobjdesc: A large plant with spiky leaves grows on the right. One of its two flowers arches above Thel's head. Long stamens dangle from the blossom on the right; the blossom on the left is less open and may be only a bud. The plant may be a combination of the flowers of the Meadia or dodecatheon, the golden amaryllis, and the leaves of the St. Bernard's lily.
A large plant with spiky leaves rises to the left of Thel. This may be the colorless monotropa or corpse-plant.
Two stems grow just left of Thel's waist. Each terminates in a small, lily-like flower.
A sprig of flowers, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily, arches to the right of the Worm's waist.
The curved form on the left margin may be the lower part of a tree trunk, a cliff, or the side of a hill.
A few wavy lines and the coloring suggest grass on the ground beneath the figures.

Thel squats on the ground, her arms folded over her chest and knees in a contracted position. Her long hair falls over her shoulders; the hem of her long gown cascades around her. She looks down at the personified Clod and Worm with head bowed.
The nude, infant Worm lies on the ground with legs crossed and arms extended at an angle of 135 degrees. His head is turned toward the Clod. There are slight indications of male genitals on the Worm.
The personified Clod or "matron Clay" (line 16) lies on the ground. She is a nude young woman with long hair. Her right arm extends under the infant Worm, perhaps reaching for him.
A small river runs near the left margin and along the full length of the lower margin. Alternatively, this water may be part of a small lake.
Because of the water on the left and in the foreground, the figures may be sitting on an island or peninsula.
The washes along the right margin suggest a sunrise or sunset.
Some of the washes beneath and on all sides of the text may indicate clouds.

l.note: The penned number ("6") is written in ink over pencil.
In Copy O, this printed number ("5") is partly obscured by a marginal design. Presumably, the inscribed number above (line 1) supersedes this number.

lg.l: But he that loves the lowly, pours his oil upon my head,
And kisses me, and binds his nuptial bands around my breast.
And says; Thou mother of my children, I have loved thee.
And I have given thee a crown that none can take away
But how this is sweet maid, I know not, and I cannot know.
I ponder, and I cannot ponder; yet I live and love.
The daughter of beauty wip'd her pitying tears with her white veil,
And said. Alas! I knew not this. and therefore did I weep:
That God would love a Worm I knew. and punish the evil foot
That wilful, bruis'd its helpless form: but that he cherish'd it
With milk and oil, I never knew; and therefore did I weep.
And I complaind in the mild air, because I fade away.
And lay me down in thy cold bed, and leave my shining lot.
Queen of the vales. the matron Clay answerd; I heard thy sighs.
And all thy moans flew o'er my roof. but I have call'd them down:
Wilt thou O Queen enter my house. 'tis given thee to enter.
And to return; fear nothing. enter with thy virgin feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three nude children ride on the back of a snake. The front-most child, apparently a girl, holds a rein in her left hand that extends to the snake's open mouth. His forked tongue is extended. Beneath the snake are a variety of vegetative forms, including leaves and roots. "The End" (line 28) is written within a hollow formed by the ground and vegetation. Washes in the text area suggest sky or clouds. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design. The design bears no direct relationship with any images or events in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: Spiky lines and the coloring in the lower margin suggest grass and perhaps small plants on the ground.
Several curved and pointed forms left of "The End" (line 28) may be leaves and/or roots.
One large leaf rests on the ground right of "The End" (line 28). This may be an oak leaf.
The form along the lower left margin may be the side of a tree trunk.
A nude young girl with long hair rides the snake's back. She holds a rein in her left hand and faces to the left.

A nude child or infant, probably male, rides on the snake's back. His legs are spread apart. He reaches back with his left arm to grasp the left hand of the infant behind him. A few lines suggest short curly hair.
A nude infant rides the snake's back nearest the tail. He faces left and reaches up with his left arm to grasp the hand of the child to the left.
A snake carries three children on his back. His mouth is open, forked tongue extended. His tail spirals into three loops.
Some of the washes in the text area may indicate sky or clouds illuminated by a sunrise or sunset.
The words "The End" (line 28) appear within a hollow formed by the ground and vegetation.

lg.l: The End

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch with a few leaves curves above the first two words of the poem (line 4). A few lines top right may indicate another sprig of vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch with a few leaves curves above the first two words of poem (line 4).
A few curving lines drawn over the etched number may be a vine or branch.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curved, horizontal line on line 19 of the text suggests a vine or branch. To the right is a bird in flight and a few lines that may be a cloud outline or a hovering figure with arms extended. Near the right margin is a cloud.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch extends horizontally on line 19 of the text.
A bird flies upward on line 19 of the text.
A few lines may represent clouds or a hovering figure, arms extended and back bent in a graceful arch, on line 19 of the text.

l.note: The penned number ("7") is written in ink over pencil.
In Copy O, this printed number ("6") is partly obscured by a marginal design. Presumably, the inscribed number above (line 1) supersedes this number.

lg.l: The eternal gates terrific porter lifted the northern bar:
Thel enter'd in & saw the secrets of the land unknown;
She saw the couches of the dead, & where the fibrous roots
Of every heart on earth infixes deep its restless twists:
A land of sorrows & of tears where never smile was seen.
She wanderd in the land of clouds thro' valleys dark, listning
Dolours & lamentations: waiting oft beside a dewy grave
She stood in silence. listning to the voices of the ground,
Till to her own grave plot she came, & there she sat down,
And heard this voice of sorrow breathed from the hollow pit -
Why cannot the Ear be closed to its own destruction?
Or the glistning Eye to the poison of a smile!
Why are Eyelids stord with arrows ready drawn,
Where a thousand fighting men in ambush lie?
Or an Eye of gifts & graces. show'ring fruits & coined
gold!
Why a Tongue impress'd with honey from every wind?
Why an Ear, a whirlpool fierce to draw creations in?
Why a Nostril wide inhaling terror trembling & affright.
Why a tender curb upon the youthful burning boy!
Why a little curtain of flesh on the bed of our desire?
The Virgin started from her seat, & with a shriek.
Fled back unhinderd till she came into the vales of
Har

desc.objtitle: THEL's Motto,, Object 8 (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Washes in the top third of the plate suggest clouds. Washes lower right may indicate water.

component.illusobjdesc: Washes at the top of the plate and on each side of "Thel's Motto" suggest clouds.
Washes along the plate's lower margin, and particularly in the bottom left corner, may represent water.

l.note: The penned number ("8") is written in ink, possibly over pencil.

lg.l: Does the Eagle know what is in the pit?
Or wilt thou go ask the Mole:
Can Wisdom be put in a silver rod?
Or Love in a golden bowl?
